awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Robust filtration membranes for harsh environment separations
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project lies primarily in its ability to stimulate growth across multiple industries. The membrane filtration technology developed allows for the separation of components of interest and value in the oil & gas, food & beverage, life sciences, textiles, and semiconductor manufacturing spaces in a more efficient manner than the methods in use today. By replacing these more expensive and energy intensive processes, the technology can provide a significant cost savings to the industrial end user, thereby generating surplus revenue, increased hiring capacity, and facilitating growth. In addition, the project will yield a societal benefit by providing a more effective and energy efficient approach for industrial process separations and wastewater treatment.

This I-Corps project further develops a robust membrane filtration technology. The membrane consists of commonly available thin-sheet silicon through which nanoscale pores are chemically etched using a simple patented process. These pores extend from one side of the silicon sheet to the other, thereby acting as channels through which water can flow. Molecules, particles, and other constituents of interest are rejected both by the physical size of the pores, and by the chemical character of the membrane surface, allowing for the removal, concentration, or separation of important components. The membrane offers a unique value proposition in that it combines a very small size cutoff offered by polymeric filters with the harsh environment compatibility of ceramic filters, while possessing excellent resistance to clogging and blockage. These properties enable low maintenance separation performance in a wide range of industrial applications where exposure to harsh environments such as high or low pH, organic solvents, and high temperatures is required.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This NSF I-Corps Project contributed extensively both directly and indirectly to the development and ongoing implementation of a robust customer discovery framework by the project team. In turn, the application of this framework to continuous market research benefited the team with respect to additional funding, technical development, and the hiring of additional members.

Entering the seven-week NSF I-Corps program, the goal of the project was to explore industrial applications and potential pain points and challenges involved in industrial separation processes, with the underlying motivation being the commercialization of a new membrane filtration technology invented by the project team. Initially, the team had preliminary knowledge of many industrial separation practices from a technical perspective, but lacked in-depth first-hand knowledge of the relevant pain points and cost-drivers from an operational and economical perspective. Within the first few days of program participation, the team had down-selected from a list of 8-10 potential target markets to only oil and gas production and refining, both at the upstream and downstream stages.

The intellectual merit of the seven-week intensive program, followed by over a year of continued customer discovery and prototyping, includes both a deep body of knowledge focused on customer needs across multiple target markets of interest, in addition to a prototype demonstration system that will help the team to showcase the ability of their solution to meet customer needs. With respect to customer discovery, which was central to the project, over 200 total stakeholder interviews have created an extremely detailed understanding of existing pain points and market needs in two primary markets ? namely treatment and recycling of oil & gas produced water in the Marcellus Basin, and the extraction of critical materials including lithium, cobalt, and nickel in the lithium-ion battery recycling process. These learnings have greatly informed the parallel development of the team?s technology, as they seek to serve the most significant market needs in these two spaces. The portion of the award that was allotted, with the permission of the NSF, towards prototyping was utilized in the production of a prototype membrane filtration system, which has proven to be extremely valuable as a demonstration tool in interactions with strategic partners, future customers, and investors. In addition, the system has yielded useful technical data central to the team?s technical development efforts. In addition, this work has ultimately resulted in four patents being granted, with two others pending.

The broader impacts of this project have been diverse and wide-ranging. The continued implementation of the customer discovery framework developed through the program, and the resulting granular understanding of the market needs ultimately contributed to the formation of a startup company by the project team, which then received grant funding support from both the NSF and ARPA-E, to pursue commercialization of the technology in the markets identified via these efforts, in addition to dilutive investment. This funding has in turn enabled further technical progress and team expansion. With respect to the broader picture, should the team ultimately achieve commercialization in the targeted markets, they stand to create significant societal, environmental, and economic benefits on a large scale. Such impacts would include job creation, expansion of the economy, and conservation of the environment through reduction of pollution and conservation of water and energy on a global scale.


Last Modified: 12/26/2021
Modified by: Roman Lubynsky
